items.title: Dominant Sabalenka reaches Brisbane final
items.summary: World number one Aryna Sabalenka reaches the final of the Brisbane International for the third year in a row with victory over Karolina Muchova.

items.title: Top four or FA Cup? - Rogers on his Villa ambitions

items.title: Watch every penalty from Wrexham's FA Cup win over Forest
items.summary: Watch every penalty as Wrexham knocked out Premier League Nottingham Forest after a 3-3 draw in the third round of the FA Cup.

items.title: Wrexham's story 'written in the stars, literally'
items.summary: Wrexham's remarkable rise continues as they knock Premier League side Nottingham Forest out of the FA Cup in dramatic fashion.

items.title: Oxford beat MK Dons in FA Cup penalty shootout
items.summary: New Oxford United boss Matt Bloomfield watches on from the stands as his side beat MK Dons on penalties to progress to the FA Cup fourth round.

items.title: Final Steps Underway for NASAâ€™s First Crewed Artemis Moon Mission
items.summary: As NASA moves closer to launch of the Artemis II test flight, the agency soon will roll its SLS (Space Launch System) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the launch pad for the first time at the agencyâ€™s Kennedy Space Center in Florida to begin final integration, testing, and launch rehearsals. NASA is â€¦
items.body: NASAâ€™s SLS (Space Launch System) rocket is seen inside High Bay 3 of the Vehicle Assembly Building as teams await the arrival of Artemis II crewmembers to board their Orion spacecraft on top of the rocket as part of the Artemis II countdown demonstration test, Saturday, Dec. 20, 2025, at NASAâ€™s Kennedy Space Center in Florida. NASA/Joel Kowsky As NASA moves closer to launch of the Artemis II test flight, the agency soon will roll its SLS (Space Launch System) rocket and Orion spacecraft to the launch pad for the first time at the agencyâ€™s Kennedy Space Center in Florida to begin final integration, testing, and launch rehearsals. NASA is targeting no earlier than Saturday, Jan. 17, to begin the multi-hour trek from the Vehicle Assembly Building to Launch Pad 39B. The four-mile journey on the crawler-transporter-2 will take up to 12 hours. Teams are working around the clock to close out all tasks ahead of rollout. However, this target date is subject to change if additional time is needed for technical preparations or weather. â€œ We are moving closer to Artemis II, with rollout just around the corner,â€ said Lori Glaze, acting associate administrator for NASAâ€™s Exploration Systems Devâ€¦

items.title: Wrexham shock Forest in shootout after six-goal thriller
items.summary: Watch highlights as Wrexham shock Nottingham Forest in an FA Cup third-round thriller, beating the Premier League side on penalties after a 3-3 draw.

items.title: 'Unacceptable to the badge' - Dyche fumes at FA Cup exit
items.summary: Sean Dyche calls for some of his Nottingham Forest players to "have a look in the mirror" after an "unacceptable" first-half performance in their FA Cup loss at Wrexham on penalties.

items.title: 'Unacceptable to the badge' - Dyche fumes at FA Cup exit
items.summary: Sean Dyche calls for some of his Nottingham Forest players to "have a look in the mirror" after an "unacceptable" first-half performance in their FA Cup loss at Wrexham on penalties.

items.title: Shipley goal helps Port Vale past Fleetwood
items.summary: Jordan Shipley scores the only goal to put Port Vale into the fourth round of the FA Cup at the expense of Fleetwood Town.

items.title: Wigan survive late scare to beat Preston in Lancashire derby
items.summary: Harrison Bettoni's lone goal seals a narrow victory for League One side Wigan Athletic, as Brad Potts' injury time equaliser for Preston North End is ruled out for offside.

items.title: O'Sullivan withdraws from Masters for medical reasons
items.summary: Eight-time champion Ronnie O'Sullivan withdraws from the Masters, which starts on Sunday, for the second year in a row on medical grounds.

items.title: Chukwuemeka secures stoppage-time point for Dortmund against Frankfurt
items.summary: Carney Chukwuemeka scores the second of two stoppage-time goals to bring Borussia Dortmund level with Eintracht Frankfurt, in a thrilling six-goal Bundesliga game.

items.title: Young Chelsea can be new Class of '92 - Rosenior
items.summary: Chelsea's young squad has the potential to grow and deliver trophies like Manchester United's famous Class of '92 side, new boss Liam Rosenior believes.

items.title: Henderson's stunning double as Ross County beat Thistle
items.summary: Jay Henderson scores within 18 seconds and adds a second within 10 minutes as bottom side Ross County mark Stuart Kettlewell's return as manager with a victory over second-top Partick Thistle in the Scottish Championship.

items.title: Edinburgh edge Gloucester with superb fightback
items.summary: Edinburgh rally from 13 points down at half-time to deliver a bonus-point win over Gloucester and keep their Champions Cup hopes alive.

items.title: Edinburgh edge Gloucester with superb fightback
items.summary: Edinburgh rally from 13 points down at half-time to deliver a bonus-point win over Gloucester and keep their Champions Cup hopes alive.

items.title: Barbeary stars as Bath retain top spot in Pool 2
items.summary: Bath close in on winning Pool 2 and securing a home last-16 game with a convincing away victory at Castres in the Investec Champions Cup.

items.title: Shaken, Not Stirred: NASAâ€™s StarBurst Aces Extreme Temperature Tests
items.summary: Heated, cooled, shaken, and settled â€“ NASAâ€™s StarBurst instrument is several steps closer to being ready for launch. The small satellite is now awaiting instrument calibration following a successful integration in Canada and rigorous testing by engineers at the agencyâ€™s Marshall Space Flight Centerâ€¦
items.body: NASAâ€™s StarBurst instrument outside a thermal vacuum chamber at NASAâ€™s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. NASA/Daniel Kocevski Heated, cooled, shaken, and settled â€“ NASA’s StarBurst instrument is several steps closer to being ready for launch. The small satellite is now awaiting instrument calibration following a successful integration in Canada and rigorous testing by engineers at the agencyâ€™s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. StarBurst is designed to detect the initial emission of short gamma-ray bursts, some of the most powerful explosions in the universe and a key indicator of neutron star mergers. This would provide valuable insight into such events, which are also detected through gravitational waves by observatories on Earth. These events are where most of the heavy metals in the universe, such as gold and platinum, are formed. To date, only one such event has been observed simultaneously in gravitational waves and gamma-rays; StarBurst is expected to find up to 10 per year. StarBurst arrived at NASA Marshall in March 2025. During its time at the center, the instrument underwent thermal testing in a vacuum chamber and flight vibratâ€¦

items.title: Arsenal monitoring Livramento - Saturday's gossip
items.summary: Arsenal monitoring Tino Livramento as a potential summer signing, Aston Villa exploring a deal for Conor Gallagher, Dominik Szoboszlai close to agreeing contract extension at Liverpool, plus more.

items.title: Muir wins in Aspen for third World Cup gold
items.summary: Great Britain's Kirsty Muir claims a third World Cup victory of her career by winning the Freeski Slopestyle event at the US Grand Prix in Aspen on Friday.

items.title: Flight Engineers Give NASAâ€™s Dragonfly Lift
items.summary: In sending a car-sized rotorcraft to explore Saturnâ€™s moon Titan, NASAâ€™s Dragonfly mission will undertake an unprecedented voyage of scientific discovery. And the work to ensure that this first-of-its-kind project can fulfill its ambitious exploration vision is underway in some of the nationâ€™s mostâ€¦
items.body: In sending a car-sized rotorcraft to explore Saturnâ€™s moon Titan, NASAâ€™s Dragonfly mission will undertake an unprecedented voyage of scientific discovery. And the work to ensure that this first-of-its-kind project can fulfill its ambitious exploration vision is underway in some of the nationâ€™s most advanced space simulation and testing laboratories. From left, Johns Hopkins APL engineers Tyler Radomsky and Felipe Ruiz install a rotor on the Dragonfly test model at the Transonic Dynamics Tunnel at NASAâ€™s Langley Research Center in Virginia. NASA Set for launch in in 2028, the Dragonfly rotorcraft is being designed and built at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory (APL) in Laurel, Maryland, with contributions from organizations around the world. On arrival in 2034, Dragonfly will exploit Titan’s dense atmosphere and low gravity to fly to dozens of locations, exploring varied environments from organic equatorial dunes to an impact crater where liquid water and complex organic materials essential to life (at least as we know it) may have existed together. Aerodynamic testing When full rotorcraft integration and testing begins in February, the team will tap into a trove oâ€¦

items.title: I Am Artemis: Dave Reynolds
items.summary: As booster manager for NASAâ€™s SLS (Space Launch System), Dave Reynoldsâ€™ path to NASA is embodied by his childhood poster of the space shuttleâ€™s Return to Flight initiative, which hangs in his office, serving as a constant reminder that his journey to the agency began decades ago. Growing up in Roy,â€¦
items.body: 3 Min Read I Am Artemis: Dave Reynolds Dave Reynolds, the booster manager for SLS (Space Launch System), works inside the Next Generation Booster Avionics Mockup at NASAâ€™s Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Alabama. Reynolds is responsible for the design, development, and flight of the boosters for the rocket that carry NASAâ€™s Orion spacecraft and astronauts to the Moon as part of the Artemis II mission. Credits: NASA As booster manager for NASAâ€™s SLS (Space Launch System), Dave Reynoldsâ€™ path to NASA is embodied by his childhood poster of the space shuttleâ€™s Return to Flight initiative, which hangs in his office, serving as a constant reminder that his journey to the agency began decades ago. Growing up in Roy, Utah, Reynolds remembers standing outside to watch the billowing smoke rise from booster tests at Northrop Grummanâ€™s Promontory facility. Rockets were the backdrop of his childhood, and growing up during the shuttle missions sparked his fascination for space exploration. As the booster manager for the SLS, Dave is responsible for the design, development, and flight of the boostersâ€”work that echoes the sense of significance that inspired him as a child to study spaâ€¦

items.title: NASAâ€™s Pandora Satellite, CubeSats to Explore Exoplanets, Beyond
items.summary: A new NASA spacecraft called Pandora is awaiting launch ahead of its journey to study the atmospheres of exoplanets, or worlds beyond our solar system, and their stars. Along for the ride are two shoebox-sized satellites called BlackCAT (Black Hole Coded Aperture Telescope) and SPARCS (Star-Planet â€¦
items.body: 6 min read NASAâ€™s Pandora Satellite, CubeSats to Explore Exoplanets, Beyond A new NASA spacecraft called Pandora is awaiting launch ahead of its journey to study the atmospheres of exoplanets, or worlds beyond our solar system, and their stars. Along for the ride are two shoebox-sized satellites called BlackCAT (Black Hole Coded Aperture Telescope) and SPARCS (Star-Planet Activity Research CubeSat) , as NASA innovates with ambitious science missions that take low-cost, creative approaches to answering questions like, â€œHow does the universe work?â€ and â€œAre we alone?â€ All three missions are set to launch Jan. 11 on a SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Space Launch Complex 4 East at Vandenberg Space Force Base in California. The launch window opens at 8:19 a.m. EST (5:19 a.m. PST). SpaceX will livestream the event. Artistâ€™s concept of NASAâ€™s Pandora mission, which will help scientists untangle the signals from the atmospheres of exoplanets â€” worlds beyond our solar system â€” and their stars. items.body: Earth Observatory Science Earth Observatory Ganges Delta Under a Winterâ€¦ Earth Earth Observatory Image of the Day EO Explorer Topics All Topics Atmosphere Land Heat & Radiation Life on Earth Human Dimensions Natural Events Oceans Remote Sensing Technology Snow & Ice Water More Content Search Collections Global Maps World of Change Articles Notes from the Field Blog Earth Matters Blog Blue Marble: Next Generation EO Kids Mission: Biomes About About Us Subscribe ğŸ›œ RSS Contact Us January 6, 2026 Winter weather took hold across the Indo-Gangetic Plain in early January 2026, bringing dense fog and cold temperatures to much of the flat, fertile lands that span from Pakistan and northern India to Bangladesh. This image shows low-lying clouds over the delta on the morning of January 6, captured by the MODIS (Moderate Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer) on NASAâ€™s Terra satellite. Dense fog, particularly radiation fog , is common this time of year, forming when ground temperatures are cool, winds are light, and moisture is abundant near the surface. The meteorological departments of both Bangladesh and India called for moderate to very dense fog over the region that day amid anâ€¦

items.title: NASA to Provide Media with International Space Station Update Today
items.summary: NASA will host a live news conference at 5 p.m. EST on Thursday from the agencyâ€™s headquarters in Washington to discuss the International Space Station and its crew. On Jan. 7, the agency announced it was postponing a planned spacewalk originally scheduled for Jan. 8 while teams monitored a medicalâ€¦
items.body: Credit: NASA NASA will host a live news conference at 5 p.m. EST on Thursday from the agencyâ€™s headquarters in Washington to discuss the International Space Station and its crew. On Jan. 7, the agency announced it was postponing a planned spacewalk originally scheduled for Jan. 8 while teams monitored a medical concern with a crew member currently living and working aboard the orbital laboratory. The matter involved a single crew member, who is stable . Due to medical privacy, it is not appropriate for NASA to share more details about the crew member. Participants in the news conference include: NASA Administrator Jared Isaacman Amit Kshatriya, associate administrator Dr. James Polk, chief health and medical officer, NASA Headquarters NASA will provide live coverage of the news conference on NASA+ , Amazon Prime , and the agencyâ€™s YouTube channel . Learn how to stream NASA content through a variety of online platforms, including social media. To participate in the news conference virtually or in-person, media must RSVP for details no later than one hour before the start of the event to the NASA Newsroom at: hq-media@mail.nasa.gov . NASAâ€™s media credentialing policy is online. To lâ€¦

items.title: NASA Starts Up Gatewayâ€™s Power System for First Time
items.summary: Development continues on NASAâ€™s Power and Propulsion Element, a solar electric propulsion spacecraft designed to provide power for Gateway in lunar orbit. Able to generate 60 kilowatts of power, the element was successfully powered on earlier last year. The milestone demonstrates the element can prâ€¦
items.body: 1 min read Preparations for Next Moonwalk Simulations Underway (and Underwater) The primary structure of Gatewayâ€™s Power and Propulsion Element (PPE) undergoing assembly, integration, and testing at Lanteris Space Systems in Palo Alto, California, on September 29, 2025. Lanteris Space Systems Development continues on NASAâ€™s Power and Propulsion Element, a solar electric propulsion spacecraft designed to provide power for Gateway in lunar orbit. Able to generate 60 kilowatts of power, the element was successfully powered on earlier last year. The milestone demonstrates the element can provide the spacecraft with power, high-rate communications, attitude control, as well as the ability to maintain and maneuver between orbits. The Power and Propulsion Element is managed by NASAâ€™s Glenn Research Center in Cleveland and built by industry partner Lanteris Space Systems in Palo Alto, California, where teams have secured the elementâ€™s main electrical system inside protective exterior panels. On deck for installation at Lanteris Space Systems are three 12-kilowatt advanced electric propulsion system thrusters, manufactured by L3Harris, and four 6-kilowatt Busek-built BHT-6000 thrusters. Thâ€¦

items.title: Meltwater Turns Iceberg A-23A Blue
items.summary: After a four-decade run, the massive, waterlogged berg is leaking meltwater and on the verge of disintegrating.
items.body: Earth Observatory Science Earth Observatory Meltwater Turns Iceberg A-23Aâ€¦ Earth Earth Observatory Image of the Day EO Explorer Topics All Topics Atmosphere Land Heat & Radiation Life on Earth Human Dimensions Natural Events Oceans Remote Sensing Technology Snow & Ice Water More Content Search Collections Global Maps World of Change Articles Notes from the Field Blog Earth Matters Blog Blue Marble: Next Generation EO Kids Mission: Biomes About About Us Subscribe ğŸ›œ RSS Contact Us December 26, 2025 The year that iceberg A-23A first broke away from Antarcticaâ€™s Filchner Ice Shelf , Ronald Reagan was president of the United States, and the movie Top Gun was setting box office records. Forty years later, the massive tabular bergâ€”one of the largest and longest-lived bergs ever tracked by scientistsâ€”is sopping with blue meltwater and on the verge of complete disintegration as it drifts in the South Atlantic between the eastern tip of South America and South Georgia island. When it first detached from Antarctica in 1986, the berg was nearly twice the size of Rhode Islandâ€”about 4,000 square kilometers. Estimates from the U.S. National Ice Center put the bergâ€™s area at 1,182 squaâ€¦
